stimulusHtml: Which of the following describes how the Mexican president is elected?
choicesHtml: The president is chosen using a plurality formula, where the candidate who wins the most votes in a single round is elected president.
The president is chosen using a majority formula, where a candidate can win only if he or she receives more than 50 percent of the vote.
If no candidate receives a majority of the vote in the first round of elections, a runoff is held between the two candidates with the most votes in the first round.
A candidate can become president only if he or she receives at least 25 percent of the vote in two-thirds of Mexicoâ€™s 32 states.
